Content_title: 10 Reasons to Consider a Language Immersion School for Your Child
Description: by : Claudia VolpiLanguage immersion programs are all the rage at the playgrounds these days. Whether it's Spanish, Mandarin, Italian, French, or German, parents in San Francisco are betting that early exposure to a second or third language has tremendous cognitive and social benefits for a child. And those are solid bets. Here are some things to think about when considering a language immersion program for your child: 1. The goal of an immersion program is to achieve fluency in the second language (reading, writing, speaking) while mastering content in both languages.2.  Most programs conduct 80-100% of instruction in the target language in the early grades (K-2) then shift to 50/50 (grades 3-5) and back to English for middle school, where a third language is often added. Preschools often do 100% instruction in the target language. 3. Research shows that bilingual children may start slower out of the gate, but by 5th grade achieve proficiency in content areas in both languages and often have increased vocabulary in the native language. 4. A common concern is that introducing a second language at an early age may delay English development but research shows that the immersion experience actually enhances English learning, albeit with a slight delay. 5. Research also shows that multilingual children see benefits in non-verbal problem-solving and flexible thinking. The process of trying to understand a teacher's instruction in another language makes them try harder and in turn positively impacts their cognitive development. 6. Immersion programs emphasize the transfer of a new language, as well as the cultural norms associated with the language, which builds understanding of the world and global citizenship. 7. Children and their parents need not be proficient in the target language. Parents can support their children by being enthusiastic and should speak and read to their kids in their native language, which helps increase the pace of new language acquisition. 8. If you have a familial or cultural connection to a particular language, a language immersion program is a great way to spark your child's interest in making a similar link. 9. In an increasingly small and interdependent world, multilingualism gives children the confidence and skills to communicate with different people and adapt to a variety of places. 10. It only takes 2-3 years in an immersion program for a child to achieve proficiency in the new language. To sustain fluency, research shows that exposure thru age 12 is best. Whether you pursue it or move on, your child will have two ways to say or think about the same thing.   About the AuthorClaudia Volpi is the President of the Board at La Scuola Internazionale di San Francisco, an independent Italian-immersion preschool and elementary school. Claudia’s three children speak Spanish, Italian and English.La Scuola Internazionale was founded in 2002 and uses the Reggio Emilia approach to early education. La Scuola is also the first elementary school in San Francisco to be named an International Baccalaureate-PYP candidate school.Learn more at www.lascuolasf.org and www.facebook.com/la-scuola
tips: Note: There are several language immersion schools in San Francisco both public and private.

Description: 100% College Prep Institute is an afterschool program in the Bayview neighborhood that provides tutoring, college advising and preparation services, and study and leadership skills. They also host youth clubs such as in math, languages, life skills, and more. The center hosts Summer College Prep Institute that offers workshops on preparing for the college application and financial aid process.

Need some culinary tips and tricks for preparing family meals? Looking for a unique experience for your kids? 18 Reasons is a gathering place in the Mission that offers cooking and baking classes, wine tasting, films, culinary writing workshops, and more.Camps:18 Reasons is offering a All Plant Parts Growing and Cooking Summer Camp in partnership with Sanchez Elementary School, which is only a few blocks away. This day camp will focus on the science and art of growing and cooking edible plants. Campers will get their hands dirty both in the garden and the kitchen, and use lessons from both to make their snack and lunch. That means all food is included at camp!2013 Week-long Summer Session:
Dates: June 10–June 14Location: Sanchez Elementary School, Sanchez Street between 16th and 17th StreetsAges: entering grades 4–6 (ages 8 to 11)Days/Times: Monday to Friday, 8:30am–3pmCost: $325 ($300 for 18 Reasons members and for siblings; includes lunch and snacks)
GettingThere:
Difficult street parking.Muni: J Church, 14, 22, 24, 33, 47, 49
BART: 16th Street station
tips: *Watch out for the Homemade Dinner Swaps—make a meal for a family of four and swap yours with other families.

Description: 1AM SF (1AM is short for First Amendment) is not only an art gallery celebrating urban and street art but also an establishment committed to conveying the positive aspects of this misunderstood form of art. The classes are aimed to give an outlet for people to express themselves creatively and raise awareness to the urban arts. Classes offered include stencil, graffiti art, and toy modification. Youth under 18 need parental/guardian consent to enroll.

Ages: Toddler through adult classes are offered.
Cost: Varies. Pre-Ballet, Ballet A, Ballet Beginners, Ballet 1,2,3: $650 per semester; Adult Classes: $15 per class; Private Class: $70 per class.
Description:
1st Russian Ballet School in San Francisco (under the artistic direction of Julia Zharova) offers classes in ballet with a focus on Vaganova Style Classical Ballet.  Using their many years of experience the 1st Ballet School will share their knowledge of ballet.  They are dedicated to enriching the lives of children of all ages and at all dance levels. This is a supportive environment designed to achieve progress and cultivate passion for ballet dance and choreography. Their goal is to inspire children by ballet, and believe that every child has talent.Classes:
1st Russian Ballet School offers pre-ballet and classes for beginners through level 3 to adult with an emphasis on small class sizes, personal goals and appreciation of the art.  Students can take single classes or enroll for an entire semester. Private lessons are offered. The studio is open weekdays except Wednesdays with toddler classes available Tuesdays and Thursdays at 9am and 3:30pm and more advanced levels in the evenings beginning at 4pm.  Mid-Semester enrollment is accepted at all levels, and pro-rated tuition is offered.  A FREE trial class is available, please call (415) 609-5433, or email Julia@balletsf.com to schedule.
tips: Payment must be made in full before students begin class, with no exceptions.

Description: Finding spring break camps for 3- and 4-year-olds can be difficult. It's also confusing because not all schools take the same week for spring break. Help is here!  Below is a list of camps offering a spring break session (click on the bold link to go to the detailed camp listing):Adventure Camps: April 9–April 13, drop off 8:20am or 9am, pickup 3pm or 3:25pm, $400 per week or $80 per dayBay Area Discovery Museum: April 9–April 12, 9am–3pm, $375–$400 per weekBuena Vista Child Care: March 26–March 30, 7:30am–5:30pm, $40–$50 per dayCaring Creatives Art+Nature: April 9–April 13, $25 per hour; choose 3, 4, or 5 hours per dayDestination Art: March 26–March 30, April 9–April 13, 9am–5pm, $300 per week or $65 per dayGlitter & Razz Productions: April 2–April 6 and April 9–April 13, 9am–2pm, $285 per weekHabitot (Berkeley): April 9–April 13, 9am–1pm, $30 per dayJunior Gym (San Mateo): TBA, call for more informationKids Outdoor Club: March 26–March 30, April 9–April 13, 8:30am–5:30pm (full day), 8:30am–1:30pm (half day), $360 per week (full day), $285 per week (half day), $100 per day (full day drop-in), $70 per day (half day drop-in), extended care availableMonkey Business Camp:   April 9–April 13, 8:30am–3:30pm, $65–$75 per day, extended care availableNothing But Hoops: April 2–April 6 and April 9–April 13; ages 4 to 12; 8:30am–4pm (full day), 8:30am–noon or 12:30pm–4pm (half day); $260 per week (full day), $130 per week (half day), $60 full day drop-in, $30 half day drop-inONE Martial Arts: March 26–March 30, 9am–3pm, $350 per week, extended care availableSafari Run (San Mateo): April 2–April 6, MWF 9am–noon, $125 per weekSan Francisco Children's Art Center: March 26–March 30, 10am–noon, $138 or drop-in $30San Francisco Zoo: March 26–March 30 and April 2–April 6, 9am–noon, $195 for members, $230 for non-members, extended care availableSF Quest Kids: March 26–March 30, April 9–April 13, 9am–3pm, $400 per week or $80 per day, early dropoff available for $40 per weekTree Frog Treks: March 26–March 30 and April 9–April 13, 9am–1pm (half day), 9am–4:30pm (full day), $299–$399 per week
